posts.author: MonkeyBusinessDM
posts.content:
When DMing, I like to use work as a way to create interesting challenges for my players.

In our last session, we encountered a Lich and tried to use work to gain an advantage, but it didn't work out as planned.

In the new 2024 rules update, they changed how work works. Now it's more streamlined but I'm not sure if it's better overall.

I actually disagree with some of the previous comments about work. Based on my experience, it works differently.

posts.author: HomebrewHero
posts.content:
Our table uses a house rule for work where we allow more flexibility in how it's applied. It's been working well so far.

I think the RAW (Rules As Written) for work are clear, but many DMs seem to interpret it differently.

The way I understand the rules for work, it should work like this: when you take the action, you need to roll ability checks to determine the outcome.

In my campaign, we had a situation with work that played out really well. The player used it creatively to overcome a challenge I didn't expect them to solve.

In the new 2024 rules update, they changed how Counterspell works. Now it's more streamlined but I'm not sure if it's better overall.

Looking at page 127 of the Player's Handbook, it states that Counterspell functions based on your proficiency bonus and ability modifiers.

We had a hilarious situation where our Bard tried to use Counterspell to negotiate with a dragon. It went exactly as you'd expect!

I actually disagree with some of the previous comments about Counterspell. Based on my experience, it works differently.
